ruleset.name: Codecop
ruleset.description: Mix of rules for various bugs and conventions. Some of these should really be in the core of PMD. Others are likely to be controversial.

rule.name: JumbledIterator
rule.message: Non matching iterator identifier found in for loop.
rule.description: The used Iterator for the 'exit expression' in a for loop does not match the 'declaration expression', most likely this is not intended.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: ParameterNameWithP
rule.message: Method parameter names must start with 'p'.
rule.description: All parameters of methods and constructors are required to be named like pXyz. Use Ctrl-1 to local rename it.

rule.name: UnintendedEnvUsage
rule.message: getBoolean, getInteger, getLong read from System Properties and do not parse.
rule.description: The methods getBoolean, getInteger and getLong read from environment (System Properties) and do not parse. Use Integer.parseInt() instead.

rule.name: JunitSetupDoesNotCallSuper
rule.message: Methods setUp and tearDown in JUnit tests must call super.setUp/tearDown.
rule.description: The framework methods setUp() and tearDown() of JUnit's Testcase must always call super.setUp() and super.tearDown() to enable proper preparing and cleaning of resources.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: InterfaceNamesEndWithIF
rule.message: Interface names should end with 'IF'.
rule.description: For better recognition interface names should end with 'IF'. Rename the interface!
rule.example: public interface SomeInterface { } // nok public interface SomeInterfaceF { } // nok public interface SomeInterfaceIF { } // ok public class SomeClass { } // ok

rule.name: InterfaceNamesStartWithI
rule.message: Interface names should start with 'I'.
rule.description: For better recognition interface names should start with 'I'. Rename the interface!
rule.example: public interface SomeInterface { } // nok public interface SomeInterface { } // nok public interface ISomeInterface { } // ok public class SomeClass { } // ok

rule.name: AtomWrapperInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Wrapper Type objects. Call Type.valueOf() instead.
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Type() causes memory allocation. Type.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

property.name: xpath

rule.example: public class AtomWrapperInstantiationExample { Byte myByte = new Byte(1); // bad Byte byte2 = Byte.valueOf(1); // ok Short myshort = new Short(20); // bad Short myshort2 = Short.valueOf(20); // ok Integer integer = new Integer(4); // bad Integer integer2 = Integer.valueOf(4); // ok Long myLong = new Long(10000000); // bad Long myLong2 = Long.valueOf(10000000); // ok Character myChar = new Character('x'); // bad Character char2 = Character.valueOf('x'); // ok }

rule.name: CharInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Character objects. Call Character.valueOf() instead.
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Character() causes memory allocation. Character.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.name: NonFinalFieldInException
rule.message: Exceptions must be immutable.
rule.description: Exceptions must be immutable, so the fields of an Exception must be declared as final.

rule.name: AvoidPrivateGetterAndSetter
rule.message: Don't use private getters/setters.
rule.description: Instead of using private getter or setter, we use the member variable instead. It's easier to read and saves lines of code.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: MembersMustBePrivate
rule.message: Members must be private except they are static and final
rule.description: Members must be private, except static final constants. Change Member to private and create getter and/or setter to access value/s.

rule.name: SignatureDeclareThrowsException
rule.message: A method/constructor shouldn't explicitly throw java.lang.Exception.
rule.description: It is unclear which exceptions that can be thrown from the methods. It might be difficult to document and understand the vague interfaces. Use either a class derived from RuntimeException or a checked exception.
rule.example: public void methodThrowingException() throws Exception { }

rule.name: ClassNamingConventions
rule.message: Class names should begin with an uppercase character, not include underscores or dollar signs.
rule.description: Class names should always begin with an upper case character, and should not contain underscores (but _Stub or _Core) or dollar signs. Class names should not be upper case only.

property.name: upperCaseLen
property.description: Allowed length of upper case only names

rule.example:
public class FOOBAR {} // bad public class Foo_Bar {} // bad public class Foo$Bar {} // bad
public class URI {} // ok - short abbrev public class Foo_Stub {} // ok - created by RMI compiler public class Foo_Core {} // ok - Generation Gap Pattern

rule.name: LoggerHasWrongCategory
rule.message: Logger has wrong category.
rule.description: Logger is created for another category than the enclosing class. This is a typical copy-paste error.

rule.name: AvoidThrowingCheckedException
rule.message: Avoid throwing checked exceptions.
rule.description: Avoid throwing checked Exceptions - it's considered noise.

rule.name: ShortVariableCustom
rule.message: Avoid variables with short names like {0}.
rule.description: Detects when a field, local, or parameter has a very short name.

rule.name: DontImportWild
rule.message: No wild card imports.
rule.description: Do not use wild card imports such as java.net.*.
rule.example: import java.net.*; // is bad import java.net.URL; // is better

rule.name: PrivateInjections
rule.message: Make injected fields private.
rule.description: Set all injected fields to private.

rule.name: JUnitTestsShouldIncludeAssertOrVerify
rule.message: JUnit tests should include at least one assertion (assert(), fail() or verify()).
rule.description: JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

rule.name: PrimitiveObsession
rule.message: Introduce a ValueObject in place of the primitive data.
rule.description: You are likely using primitive data types to represent domain ideas. For example, a String to represent a message, an Integer to represent an amount of money, or a Struct/Dictionary/Hash to represent a specific object. You should introduce a ValueObject in place of the primitive data.

property.name: checkConstructors
property.description: Check public constructors for more than one primitive

rule.name: MutableException
rule.message: Avoid non final attributes in exceptions.
rule.description: Exception instances should represent an error condition. Having non final fields allows the state to be modified by accident and therefore mask the original condition.

rule.name: ImmutablesOnly
rule.message: Avoid mutable state, make all fields final.
rule.description: Immutable data structures are easier to reason about and have no concurrency issues. Only final fields are allowed. (Mutable field references should be copied when passed in or out, but that is not checked.)

rule.name: OneLevelOfIntention
rule.message: Only one Level of intention per method.
rule.description: Use only one level of intention per method. You cannot use if, loops or try more than once in a method. If used they need to be the first/last/outer statement of the method. This enforces SRP split on method level. This is rule 1 of Object Calisthenics.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: FirstClassCollections
rule.message: Any class that contains a collection (or array) should contain no other member variables.
rule.description: Each collection gets wrapped in its own class, so now behaviour related to the collection have a home. Constants do not count. This is rule 4 of Object Calisthenics.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: AvoidClassNamingImpl
rule.message: Implementation classes should not end with 'Impl'.
rule.description: For better naming implementation classes should not end with 'Impl'. Rename the class!
rule.example: public class SomeImpl { } // nok public class SomeClass { } // ok

rule.name: TestNameShouldStartWithShould
rule.message: Test method must start with 'should'.
rule.description: Write your tests in the behaviour driven development style of testing, as it encourages you to write tests that read as specifications, and are more aligned with the behaviour of the class or system that you are testing.

property.name: classSuffix
property.description: Suffix to test class names (to identify)

rule.name: NoCasts
rule.message: Do not cast objects, use polymorphy.
rule.description: Type casting an object to a subclass' type is not object oriented. Use polymorphy to access the behaviour you need.
